 30 -class VectorObservation(object): 

 31      """ 
 32      Base class for all vector observation methods. 
 33   
 34      Vector observation methods calculate the L{Quaternion} that rotates a 
 35      set of reference vectors to match the set of observed vectors. 
 36      Vectors are assumed to be 3x1 L{np.ndarray}s 
 37      """ 
 38   
 39      __metaclass__ = ABCMeta 
 40   

 41 -    def __call__(self, *measurements): 

 42          """ 
 43          Estimate the orientation Quaternion from the observed vectors. 
 44   
 45          @param measurements: The observed vectors (3x1 L{np.ndarray}) 
 46          @return: The estimated orientation L{Quaternion} 
 47          """ 
 48          if any(map(lambda a: np.any(np.isnan(a)), measurements)): 
 49              return Quaternion(np.nan,np.nan,np.nan,np.nan) 
 50          else: 
 51              return self._process(*measurements) 

 52   
 53      @abstractmethod 

 54 -    def _process(self, *measurements): 

 55          """ 
 56          Internal method to be implemented by subclasses 
 57   
 58          Implementations should return the L{Quaternion} that rotates the 
 59          reference vectors to match the passed vector observations 
 60   
 61          @param measurements: The observed vectors (3x1 L{np.ndarray}) 
 62          @return: The estimated orientation L{Quaternion} 
 63          """ 
 64          pass

 66 -class TRIAD(VectorObservation): 

 67      """ 
 68      Implementation of the TRIAD vector observation algorithm. 
 69   
 70      The algorithm is designed to estimation the orientation based on 
 71      observations of the Earth gravitational and magnetic fields based on the 
 72      assumption of a (X,Y,Z) -> (North,East,Down) co-ordinate frame 
 73   
 74      See M.D. Shuster, and S.D. Oh "Three-Axis Attitude Determination from 
 75      Vector Observations" in Journal of Guidance and Control v.4 pp 70-77. 
 76      1981 
 77      """ 
 78   

 79 -    def _process(self, g, m): 

 80          """ 
 81          Estimate the orientation Quaternion from the observed vectors. 
 82   
 83          @param g: the observed gravitational field vector (3x1 L{np.ndarray}) 
 84          @param m: the observed magnetic field vector (3x1 L{np.ndarray}) 
 85          @return: The estimated orientation L{Quaternion} 
 86          """ 
 87          z = g / vectors.norm(g) 
 88          y = vectors.cross(z, m) 
 89          y /= vectors.norm(y) 
 90          x = vectors.cross(y, z) 
 91   
 92          return Quaternion.fromVectors(x, y, z) 

 93   

 94 -class GramSchmidt(VectorObservation): 

 95      """ 
 96      Vector observation based on Gram-Schmidt Ortho-Normalisation. 
 97   
 98      The algorithm is designed to estimation the orientation based on 
 99      observations of the Earth gravitational and magnetic fields based on the 
100      assumption of a (X,Y,Z) -> (North,East,Down) co-ordinate frame 
101      """ 
102   
103      @prepend_method_doc(TRIAD) 

104 -    def _process(self, g, m): 

105          z = g / vectors.norm(g) 
106          x = m - (z * vectors.dot(m, z)) 
107          x /= vectors.norm(x) 
108          y = vectors.cross(z, x) 
109   
110          return Quaternion.fromVectors(x, y, z)

112 -class FQA(VectorObservation): 

113      """ 
114      Implementation of the Factored Quaternion Algorithm by Yun et al. 
115   
116      The algorithm is designed to estimation the orientation based on 
117      observations of the Earth gravitational and magnetic fields based on the 
118      assumption of a (X,Y,Z) -> (North,East,Down) co-ordinate frame 
119   
120      See X. Yun, E. Bachmann, and R. McGhee "A Simplified Quaternion-Based 
121      Algorithm for Orientation Estimation from Earth Gravity and Magnetic 
122      Field Measurements" In IEEE Trans. on Instrumentation and Measurement 
123      v. 57 pp 638-650 2008 
124      """ 

125 -    def __init__(self): 

126          """ 
127          Initialise vector observation. 
128          """ 
129          alpha = np.radians(20) 
130          self.qAlpha = Quaternion(math.cos(alpha/2), 0, math.sin(alpha/2), 0) 
131          self.thetaThreshold = 0.1 

132   

133 -    def cosHalfAngle(self, cosAngle): 

134          """ 
135          Compute the value of cos(angle/2) from cos(angle) 
136   
137          @param cosAngle: cosine of angle (float) 
138          """ 
139   
140          if -1.0001 < cosAngle <= -1: 
141              cosAngle = -1 
142          return math.sqrt((1+cosAngle)/2) 

143   

144 -    def sinHalfAngle(self, cosAngle, sinAngle): 

145          """ 
146          Compute the value of sin(angle/2) from cos(angle) and sin(angle) 
147   
148          @param cosAngle: cosine of angle (float) 
149          @param sinAngle: sine of angle (float) 
150          """ 
151          if 1 <= cosAngle < 1.0001: 
152              cosAngle = 1 
153          sign =  1 if sinAngle >= 0 else -1 
154          return sign * math.sqrt((1-cosAngle)/2) 

155   
156      @prepend_method_doc(TRIAD) 

157 -    def _process(self, g, m): 

158          # Algorithm assumes that gravity vector is -z in default position 
159          # This is contrary to the other algorithm so we invert 
160          g = -g 
161          g /= vectors.norm(g) 
162          # Pitch 
163          sinTheta = g[0] 
164          cosTheta = math.sqrt(1 - sinTheta**2) 
165   
166          flag = cosTheta <= self.thetaThreshold 
167          if flag: 
168              # If flag is set then theta is close to zero. Rotate coord frame 20 
169              # degrees to reduce errors 
170              g = self.qAlpha.rotateFrame(g) 
171              m =  self.qAlpha.rotateFrame(m) 
172   
173              sinTheta = g[0] 
174              cosTheta = math.sqrt(1 - sinTheta**2) 
175   
176          cosHalfTheta = self.cosHalfAngle(cosTheta) 
177          sinHalfTheta = self.sinHalfAngle(cosTheta, sinTheta) 
178          qp = Quaternion(cosHalfTheta, 0, sinHalfTheta, 0) 
179   
180          # Roll 
181          cosPhi =  -g[2] / cosTheta 
182          sinPhi =  -g[1] / cosTheta 
183          cosHalfPhi = self.cosHalfAngle(cosPhi) 
184          sinHalfPhi = self.sinHalfAngle(cosPhi, sinPhi) 
185          qr = Quaternion(cosHalfPhi, sinHalfPhi, 0, 0) 
186          # Yaw 
187          m = qr.rotateVector(m) 
188          m = qp.rotateVector(m) 
189          Mx = m[0] 
190          My = m[1] 
191          scale = 1 / math.sqrt(Mx**2 + My**2) 
192          Mx *= scale 
193          My *= scale 
194   
195          # From Yun paper 
196          #cosPsi = Mx * self.Nx + My * self.Ny 
197          #sinPsi = Mx * self.Ny - My * self.Nx 
198          # but we know that Ny is 0 so this simplifies to 
199          cosPsi = Mx 
200          sinPsi = -My 
201          cosHalfPsi = self.cosHalfAngle(cosPsi) 
202          sinHalfPsi = self.sinHalfAngle(cosPsi, sinPsi) 
203          qy = Quaternion(cosHalfPsi, 0, 0, sinHalfPsi) 
204          combined = qy * qp * qr 
205   
206          if flag: 
207              return combined * self.qAlpha.conjugate 
208          else: 
209              return combined 

210   

211 -class LeastSquaresOptimalVectorObservation(VectorObservation): 

212      """ 
213      Base class of least squares optimal vector observation algorithms 
214   
215      Implementations provide optimal solutions to Wahba's loss function. See 
216      G. Wahba "A Least Squares Estimate of Satellite Attitude" SIAM review v.7 
217      pp 384-386 1965 
218   
219      @ivar refs: L{np.ndarray} of reference vectors in world frame 
220      @ivar weights: L{np.ndarray} of weights to apply to reference vectors 
221      """ 
222   

223 -    def __init__(self, refs=None, weights=None, inclinationAngle=None): 

224          """ 
225          Initialise vector observation algorithm. 
226   
227          The set of reference vectors for the vector observation process can 
228          be supplied directly, or an magnetic field inclination angle can be 
229          supplied to indicate that the reference vectors should be the Earth 
230          gravitational and magnetic fields. 
231   
232          An optional weights list can be supplied to support weighting of 
233          reference vectors when calculating the Wahba loss function. 
234   
235          @param refs: list of reference vectors (3x1 L{np.ndarray}) 
236          @param weights: list of reference vector wieghts (float) 
237          @param inclinationAngle: inclination angle of magnetic field (float) 
238          """ 
239          assert refs is not None or inclinationAngle is not None, \ 
240                  "Must specify reference vectors or inclination angle" 
241          if refs is None: 
242              refs = [ 
243                  np.array([[0,0,1.0]]).T, 
244                  np.array([[math.cos(math.radians(inclinationAngle)), 
245                      0, math.sin(math.radians(inclinationAngle))]]).T] 
246          if weights is None: 
247              weights = [1.0 for ref in refs] 
248   
249          self.refs = np.asarray(refs) 
250          self.weights = np.asarray(weights) / sum(weights) 

251   

252 -class DavenportQ(LeastSquaresOptimalVectorObservation): 

253      """ 
254      Implementation of the Davenport-q algorithm. 
255   
256      See F. Markley, and D. Mortari "Quaternion Attitude Estimation using 
257      Vector Observations" Journal of the Astronomical Sciences v.48 pp 359-380 
258      2000 
259      """ 

260 -    def _process(self, *meas): 

261          """ 
262          Estimate the orientation Quaternion from the observed vectors. 
263   
264          @param meas: The observed vectors (3x1 L{np.ndarray}) 
265          @return: The least squares optimal L{Quaternion} 
266          """ 
267          B = sum([a * np.dot(b, r.T) 
268              for a,b,r in zip(self.weights, meas, self.refs)]) 
269          S = B + B.T 
270          z = sum([a * vectors.cross(b, r) 
271              for a,b,r in zip(self.weights, meas, self.refs)]) 
272   
273          sigma = np.trace(B) 
274          K = np.empty((4,4)) 
275          K[0:3,0:3] = S-sigma*np.identity(3) 
276          K[0:3,3] = z[:,0] 
277          K[3,0:3] = z[:,0] 
278          K[3,3] = sigma 
279   
280          eigenValues,eigenVectors = np.linalg.eig(K) 
281          q = np.asarray(eigenVectors[:,np.argmax(eigenValues)]) 
282   
283          return Quaternion(q[3],q[0],q[1],q[2]).normalise() 

284   

285 -class QUEST(LeastSquaresOptimalVectorObservation): 

286      """ 
287      Implementation of the QUEST algorithm. 
288   
289      See M.D. Shuster, and S.D. Oh "Three-Axis Attitude Determination from 
290      Vector Observations" in Journal of Guidance and Control v.4 pp 70-77. 
291      1981 
292      """ 

293 -    def _apply(self, refs, meas): 

294   
295          B = sum([a * np.dot(m, r.T) for a,m,r in zip(self.weights, meas, refs)]) 
296          S = B + B.T 
297          Z = sum([a * vectors.cross(m, r) for a,m,r in zip(self.weights, meas, refs)]) 
298   
299          sigma = np.trace(B) 
300          kappa = ((S[1,1]*S[2,2] - S[1,2]*S[2,1]) + 
301                   (S[0,0]*S[2,2] - S[0,2]*S[2,0]) + 
302                   (S[0,0]*S[1,1] - S[0,1]*S[1,0])) 
303          # where did the above come from and why doesn't this work instead?: 
304          # kappa = np.trace(np.matrix(S).H) 
305          delta = np.linalg.det(S) 
306   
307          if len(refs) == 2: 
308              # Closed form solution for lambdaMax, see Shuster 1979 eqs 72-3. 
309              cosTerm = vectors.dot(*refs)[0]*vectors.dot(*meas)[0] + \ 
310                  vectors.norm(vectors.cross(*refs))*vectors.norm(vectors.cross(*meas)) 
311              lambdaMax = math.sqrt(np.sum(self.weights**2) + 2*np.product(self.weights)*cosTerm) 
312          else: 
313              # Iterate for lambdaMax, using substitutions from Shuster JAS1290 paper 
314              # for better numerical accuracy. 
315              a = sigma**2 - kappa 
316              b = sigma**2 + np.dot(Z.T, Z)[0,0] 
317              c = 8 * np.linalg.det(B) 
318              d = np.dot(Z.T, np.dot(np.dot(S,S), Z))[0,0] 
319              f = lambda l: (l**2 - a)*(l**2 - b) - c*l + c*sigma - d 
320              fprime = lambda l: 4*l**3 -2*(a+b)*l + c 
321              lambdaMax = newton(f, 1.0, fprime) 
322   
323          alpha = lambdaMax**2 - sigma**2 + kappa 
324          beta = lambdaMax - sigma 
325          gamma = (lambdaMax + sigma)*alpha - delta 
326          X = np.dot(alpha*np.identity(3) + beta*S + np.dot(S,S), Z) 
327   
328          return [gamma] + list(X[0:3,0]) 

329   
330      @prepend_method_doc(DavenportQ) 

331 -    def _process(self, *meas): 

332   
333          meas = [m / vectors.norm(m) for m in meas] 
334   
335          EPS = 1e-8 
336   
337          # Rotate the frame as necessary to avoid singularities. 
338          # See Shuster 1979 eqs 74-76. 
339   
340          # Note differences in quaternion permutations from Shuster's paper. 
341          # These ones work, why don't the ones given in the paper? 
342          p = self._apply(self.refs, meas) 
343          if abs(p[0]) < EPS: 
344              refs = [r*np.array([[1,-1,-1]]).T for r in self.refs] 
345              p = self._apply(refs, meas) 
346              if abs(p[0]) < EPS: 
347                  refs = [r*np.array([[-1,1,-1]]).T for r in self.refs] 
348                  p = self._apply(refs, meas) 
349                  if abs(p[0]) < EPS: 
350                      refs = [r*np.array([[-1,-1,1]]).T for r in self.refs] 
351                      p = self._apply(refs, meas) 
352                      q = Quaternion(p[3], p[2], -p[1], -p[0]) 
353                  else: 
354                      q = Quaternion(p[2], -p[3], -p[0], p[1]) 
355              else: 
356                  q = Quaternion(-p[1], p[0], -p[3], p[2]) 
357          else: 
358              q = Quaternion(p[0], p[1], p[2], p[3]) 
359   
360          q.normalise() 
361   
362          return q
